# Box-spring

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article is about the frame used to support a mattress. For the spring in
Yellowstone Park, see [Box Spring](/wiki/Box_Spring "Box Spring"). For other
uses, see [Box Springs](/wiki/Box_Springs_\(disambiguation\) "Box Springs
\(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-
new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg)|
This article **needs additional citations
for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**.
Please help [improve this article](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Box-
spring&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable
sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1
"Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may
be challenged and removed. _(March 2013)__([Learn how and when to remove this
template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance
template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Bassett_queen_size_box-
spring_on_metal_bed_frame.JPG/220px-Bassett_queen_size_box-
spring_on_metal_bed_frame.JPG)](/wiki/File:Bassett_queen_size_box-
spring_on_metal_bed_frame.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Bassett_queen_size_box-spring_on_metal_bed_frame.JPG "Enlarge")

Queen size box-spring on metal bed frame

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Eight-way-hand-tied-
boxspring_Shifman.jpg/220px-Eight-way-hand-tied-
boxspring_Shifman.jpg)](/wiki/File:Eight-way-hand-tied-boxspring_Shifman.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Eight-way-hand-tied-boxspring_Shifman.jpg "Enlarge")

8-way hand-tied box spring

A **box-spring** (or **divan** in some countries) is a type of [bed
base](/wiki/Bed_base "Bed base") typically consisting of a sturdy wooden frame
covered in [cloth](/wiki/Cloth "Cloth") and containing
[springs](/wiki/Spring_\(device\) "Spring \(device\)"). Usually the box-spring
is placed on top of a wooden or metal [bedframe](/wiki/Bedframe "Bedframe")
that sits on the floor and acts as a brace, except in the UK where the divan
is more often fitted with small [casters](/wiki/Caster "Caster"). The box-
spring is usually the same size as the much softer [mattress](/wiki/Mattress
"Mattress") that is placed on it. Working together, the box-spring and
mattress (with optional bed frame) make up a bed. It is common to find a box-
spring and mattress being used together without the support of a frame
underneath, the box spring being mounted directly on casters standing on the
floor.

The purpose of the box-spring is threefold:

  * to raise the mattress's height, making it easier to get in and out of [bed](/wiki/Bed "Bed");
  * to absorb shock and reduce wear to the mattress; and
  * to create a flat and firm structure for the mattress to lie upon.

The first rectangular spring-cushioned wire frames to support mattresses did
not have wood rims or cloth covers. These were called **bedsprings**. More and
more box-springs are being made out of wood, then covered in fabrics. Wood
makes a better support system for the newer memory foam and latex mattresses.
The newest design in box-springs is the folding box spring made of wood or
metal, then covered in fabric which can fold in half and can be sent by
shipping and courier companies.[1]

With the increasing height of mattresses, manufacturers now make box springs
in different heights so that the mattress and box spring pair maintain a
standard height. Standard "high profile" box springs are 9 inches (23 cm) in
height, whereas "low profile" box springs are between 5 and 5.5 inches (13 and
14 cm). Changing the thickness of the box spring and mattress require
revisions to the mattress and box spring coil stiffness. This is often why box
spring and mattress are matched and sold in pairs.

## Alternatives[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Box-spring&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Alternatives")]

Box-spring beds are especially popular in North America and Western Europe.

Alternatively, in Japan, [futon](/wiki/Futon "Futon") mattresses are usually
either placed on a bedframe or on the floor, without the use of springs.

In Europe, wooden frames with a middle section consisting of springs held in
place by wire (to be put into the wooden bedframe as a unit) used to be the
standard for most of the 20th century.  
The springs have mostly been replaced by pre-bent wooden slats (usually
[glulam](/wiki/Glulam "Glulam") made from [beech](/wiki/Beech "Beech") or
[birch](/wiki/Birch "Birch")) which are joined to the outer wooden frame by
some form of flexible rubber [bolt](/wiki/Bolt_\(fastener\) "Bolt
\(fastener\)"), shoe or socket. This lath floor provides suspension, allows
the mattress to ventilate, and can be designed to be vertically adjustable in
order to elevate the legs and / or the [torso](/wiki/Torso "Torso").  
A more simple approach is to join straight [laths](/wiki/Lath "Lath") with a
textile strap so that they can be rolled up for transport and placed right
into the bedframe.

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/30px-Commons-logo.svg.png) | Wikimedia Commons has media related to _**[Box-spring](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Box-spring "commons:Category:Box-spring")**_.  
---|---

qa.question: what is a box spring called in the uk

nq_294053_50.Query Analysis: The query seeks to identify the term used in the UK for what is commonly known as a 'box spring' in other regions.
nq_294053_50.Answer Analysis: The answer provides the term 'divan' as the UK equivalent of a box spring.
nq_294053_50.Document Content Analysis: The document appears to be a series of references and citations related to a blog post about the theatre production 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'. It includes URLs, dates, and sources but does not contain any information about furniture or terminology related to bedding.
nq_294053_50.Document and Query Keywords Matching: None of the query keywords ('box spring', 'UK', 'term') are found in the document.
nq_294053_50.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The term 'divan' is not mentioned in the document.
nq_294053_50.Key Information Matching: There is no matching key information related to the query or the answer in the document.
nq_294053_50.Can the Document Answer the Query: No, the document does not contain any information relevant to the query.
nq_294053_50.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: No, the document provides no context or additional information related to the query.
nq_294053_50.Explanation: The document is entirely unrelated to the query. It focuses on theatre productions and citations, with no mention of furniture or terminology. Therefore, it cannot answer the query or provide any useful context.

nq_2220_2.Explanation: The document is directly related to the query as it provides the exact term used in the UK for a box spring ('divan') and offers additional relevant information about box springs in the UK context.
